SENT.plain: A case study is reported of an aphasic patient, RB, who showed frequent form-related whole-word substitutions in oral naming, writing to dictation, and reading aloud
In both written language tasks, the abstractness of the targets influenced the number of formal errors
In oral naming, a high proportion of formal paraphasias was related to the intended words in both form and meaning
A comparison between targets and formal paraphasias indicated a high agreement both in word class, number of syllables, stress pattern, and in basic (stressed) vowels
The agreement in consonants (including word-initial consonants), however, was low
It is argued that RB's formal substitutions are not caused solely by errors of lexical selection but that semantic, lexical, and segmental factors contribute to the error outcome
